title: council smoking vaping ban staff off premises dundee
story: Dundee City Council has said it wants to reduce the number of adult role models seen with cigarettes in public and does not distinguish between fags and e-cigs.The city has some of the highest rates of smoking in the UK, while men in the city have some of the lowest le expectancy rates.Council bosses in Dundee said they want to reduce the number of adult role models seen with cigarettes in public and does not distinguish from other tobacco products of the lowest le expectancy rates.It would make them the first council in the UK to introduce the ban.The local authority plans to promote positive health messages and protect the health of employees.A stringent new policy told staff that anyone not complying would be subject to disciplinary action - includingthey smoked in the street, stepped off the premises to have a fag during a tea break, or were travelling to a dferent location.Employees would be punished eventhey were not wearing anything to identity them as council staff.The zero-tolerance policy has been greeted with dismay by Unison, which said banning e-cigs and vapes was not supporting smokers trying to give up fags.And campaign group Forest, which describes itself as the voice and friend of the smoker said the new policy was a form of bullying.Director Simon Clark said: Threatening employees with disciplinary actionthey smoke during work breaks or while theyre working out of doors, out of unorm and between locations is tantamount to bullying.Smoking is not illegal.If it doesnt interfere with their work or inconvenience colleagues, employees who wish to smoke outside during work breaks should be allowed to do so.A ban on vaping makes even less sense. Switching to e-cigarettes has helped a signicant number of smokers in their efforts to quit.If there is a genuine desire to help employees stop smoking, smokers should be encouraged to vape, not threatened with the same penalties as those caught smoking.He added: Smoking or vaping, the council is over-reaching its powers.Policing our lestyle, as long as it doesnt have a direct impact on our work or colleagues, is not the business of local government.A spokesman for Unison said: There are clear aspects of this policy we could not agree to.We are usually very supportive of anti-smoking policies.However, people who do smoke need to be able to take breaks and get support from their employer to help them give up.A spokesman for Dundee City Council said: The council has revised its smoking policy as we are working to protect the health of employees and also promote positive health messages across the wider community, in line with the agreed Our People Strategy and health and wellbeing framework.A key part of that approach involves discouraging children and young people from taking up smoking.One way to assist that is to reduce the number of adult role models who can be seen smoking in public.Across Dundee, there has been the introduction of voluntary no-smoking areas at childrens play parks and we will be looking to extend this to more open spaces in the future.

title: pensioner 90 made hundreds of foul mouthed 999 calls demanding pasties and lifts to bingo
story: Lena Taylor was convicted of making nuisance calls to the emergency services in July, and received a two-year conditional discharge.The -year-old was back in court last month having made another  calls to the emergency services between July  and August , Chronicle Live reports.But the determined OAP, of Wallsend, Tyneside made her hat trick of appearances in the dock this week following a further nine abusive phone calls.Taylor walked free from North Tyneside Magistrates Court after pleading guilty to a malicious communications offence.Lee Poppett, prosecuting, said: Mrs Taylor was abusive during the course of those telephone calls using foul and abusive language and not in fact reporting any emergency incident.The court heard that between July  and August , Taylor had been a great strain on resources and had an ambulance sent to her house on four occasions.Taylor was taken to hospital on one occasion but the other three times she did not need hospital treatment.During one call on July , she rang saying Ive done my dinner, I need someone to take me to bingo to keep me calm. Stop f****** messing around with me. Im not going to sit in this house all day.A few days later she demanded an ambulance and said: I want them here now. Bring me a cup of tea and a pasty. Hurry up Im starving.And in yet another call she said: My pastys f****** fell on the floor you stupid c***s, get the ambulance out now.But despite her repeated appearances before the court, it was revealed Taylor has continued to make abusive phone calls in the last few days.The court heard that Taylor has made  calls to the emergency services in the last three days.Mark Harrison, defending, said: She has almost this compulsion to ring the emergency services.She doesnt wake up in the morning wondering who to abuse next.The plan is to occupy her time, the plan is to alleviate her loneliness, the plan is to put her in touch with others who can provide help and support.Taylor was handed a  month community order and ordered her to pay £ court costs and an £ victim surcharge.

title: brexit vote maps uk reveals two countries
story: In recent months the campaign for a second referendum or so-called Peoples Vote has gathered momentum - but the nation remains as ided as it was more than two years ago.Now two fascinating maps created by mapping and analytics company Esri UK, reveal how the two Britains would lookstay or leave heartlands were cut out and replaced with lakes or sea.This is based on the results of the  EU poll.Essentially Leave Land is most of the English mainland with a hardcore in the Midlands and the North of England.  Large parts of Wales are also included.  The North East is preserved in the new Brexit nation, including Sunderland whose huge vote for Leave was the defining moment of EU referendum result night.But a large lake lies where Newcastle was because it narrowly voted for Remain. The South West and East Anglia are mostly interact.The map starkly reflects Brexiteer strongholds such as Castle Point, Essex, where . percent voted leave which was the third-highest Brexit vote of any local authority. But south of Leave Land has been eroded by huge new waterways reflecting stronger support for remain in cities.Of course London and much of the Home Counties out of the country are conspicuously missing from Leave Land.Ferries from the continent could dock in Brighton via the “Middlesex Sea” and sail up to the way to Swindon. Perhaps the layout reflects the perception among many Brexit voters that the well-off and out-of-touch elite vote Remain and they mostly live in UK capital and its surrounding areas.The highest Eemain votes in the country are . percent in Lambeth and . percent in Hackney.  But the Remainers new nation is anchored by Scotland. Here all  council areas voted to stay in the EU in the  referendum. Remain Land also includes the greater part of Northern Ireland which is has been entangled in months of negotiations over the future of the border with the Irish Republic. The largest London-based island parts of nearby counties such as Surrey, Berkshire, Buckinghamshire and Oxfordshire, which also rejected Brexit.Further north remain hangs on to densely populated islands in the North West, including central Manchester.Also in Remain Land is much of the county of Merseyside, Liverpool, Wirral and Sefton which has over the years benefited from EU investment. But no all urban areas are pro-Remain. Birmingham and Sheffield the most prominent cities voted to Leave.There is the Great Britain Ocean in the West Midlands, the Sea of Humber, the Yorkshire Shallows.The North Sea Gulfmark carved out the huge chunks of land where remain was given the boot.

title: true story behind peterloo massacre
story: NewsThe true story behind Peterloo: The massacre that changed Britain thats not taught in schoolsMike Leigh brings the epic tale of the half-forgotten atrocity to the big screen with Peterloo, starring Maxine PeakeShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsPETERLOO featuring The Manchester and Salford Yeomanry courtesy of Amazon Studios."Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIT was a scene so “truly bloody and horric” no pen could do justice to the reality. More than  mounted troops, swords specially sharpened, charged into a crowd of peaceful demonstrators. One witness told of women’s heads scythed in half and “tender offshyshyspring drenched in their mothers’ blood”. Others recalled a “most terric shriek” piercing the air and people trampled or pushed into cellars by the panshyshyshyshyicked crowd only to be crushed to death. One truncheon-wielding constable screamed at the pro-democracy demonstrators: “This is Watershyshyloo for you.” Indeed, the carnage was so appalling it was immediately compared with Wellington’s famous,bloody, victory of four years earlier and dubbed “Peterloo”.  For generations it was a footnote in history classes. Children learned of Trafalgar, the defeat of Napoleon and the rise of the British Empire. Only now, thanks to a new film by Mike Leigh, is this seismic moment getshyshyting the attention it deserves. It is hard to believe as you walk round the site in central Manchester that here unfolded one of the most controversial episodes in our history. What was then St Peter’s Fields is now covered with monuments to Victorian prosperity. Right in the middle stands the Midland Hotel where Theresa May and the Cabinet stay when the Tory conference is in town. The narrow streets down which the demonstrators tried to flee only to find themselves in suffocating bottlenecks have been replaced by a plaza in front of the Convention Centre.  The spot where Henry “Orator” Hunt addressed the crowd is now the Radisshyshyson Hotel. Only a small red plaque on the side of the building stands as a reminder to the blood which flowed on that Monday of August , . At least , people, one of largest crowds ever recorded at that date, gathered to challenged the iniquity that a region of , souls did not have a single MP. Weavers, labshyshyourers, artisans, farm hands, women and children – many in their Sunday best – had brought picnics and musical instruments.  They had come to listen to Hunt. His eyes would go red with passion when he spoke about the unfairness of large rapidly growing industrial cities having no representation in Parliament while a handful of voters in ancient, tiny, “rotten boroughs” were able toeasily bribed MPs. When Hunt took to the stage, a couple of carts lashed together, just beshyshyshyshyshyfore pm the magistrates ordered the charge. Dozens of blue-coated soldiers, who had spent the morning drinking after assembling in Pickford’s Yard , rode into the crowd with sabres drawn. The first victim was William Fyles, two, who was trampled to death. Women and children were cut down “inshyshyshydisshyshyshycriminately”, according to one report. One man had his nose sliced off, another was beaten so badly “there was not a place on his back that was not covered with wounds or bruises”.  Socialist historian Michael Herbert says: “People were lying in heaps because they could not escape. There were only narrow streets so there was no way out. “Some fell into cellars and were crushed. The worst was nearest the stage where the crowd was thickest.” Up to  people were killed and an estimated  injured. Ten journalists from across the country were there to witness the barbarity. Every bruise, sabre cut and innocent le lost was recorded for posterity. Thomas Barlow of Middleton was “sabred in the head and much crushed”. John Davenport of Stockport had a bone “the size of half-a-crown” hacked from his forehead and Margaret Downes, “dreadfully cut in the breast”, was “secshyshyreted clandestinely and supposed dead”.  What made the massacre so monshyshystrous was the crowd was peaceful and the attack was authorised in advance. Magistrate William Hulton was not going to allow a gathering of the “lower orders” and their radical cheerleaders. The authorities, as so often before and since, tried to cover up the outrages. Inquests were abandoned and “fake news” planted in sympathetic papers lied about demonstrators attacking troops with stones. Not a single person was convicted. Nobody was ever held to account. Not content with shting the blame, the Government then went on the offensive. Hunt was imprisoned. So, too, was Times journalist John Tyas who desshyshycribed the bloodbath. A stamp tax was introduced to gag newspapers and bans on public assembly were introduced. But did the victims die in vain  Historian Dr Robert Poole believes not. He says: “It was a massive setback but in the end we got most of what the Peterloo generation was after.” Within  years the Great Reform Act was passed, granting Manchester two MPs. However, working people’s struggle for the vote was to last much, much longer. In  males who owned or rented property of a certain value were enfranchised. But it was not until  that all men – and some women over  – got the vote. And women under  had to wait until . Maxine Peake speaks of pride at playing Hillsborough campaigner Anne Williams in ITV drama from creators of BodyguardManchester-raised director Mike Leigh says he was inshyshyshycreasshyshyshyingly aware of the film’s signicance as shooting proshyshygressed. He adds: “Those who were fighting for the vote would be horried to find that  years later we have it but we don’t use it.” Dr Poole puts Peterloo in the same category as Bloody Sunday, Tiananmen Square and the Soweto riots – a sacrice of innocents leading to eventual progress. Others draw parshyshyshyallels with Hillsborough and the miners’ strike in the way the authorities tried to cover up wrongdoing and smear victims. Leigh echoes the sentiment. “It was an important event in the long road to democracy. Some say, ‘So what  It didn’t achieve anything immediately’. “I don’t subscribe to that. It stands as an inspiration to freedom of expression and democracy. And it was about people’s right to demand what they haven’t got.”Peterloo, starring Maxine Peake, is in cinemas now.Win visit to carnage city To mark the bicentenary of Peterloo and Mike Leigh’s film, we’ve teamed up with Visit Manchester to offer an overnight night stay for two in the luxurious Radisson Blu Edwardian, plus a meal for two in Peter Street Kitchen restaurant, two tickets to see Peterloo at Home cinema, a meal for two at Home restaurant and a poster signed by Mike Leigh. For a chance to win, answer the question at visitmanchester Peterloo. Q: When will Manchester mark the bicentenary of the Peterloo Massacre  a  b  c . Visit Manchesters website

title: archaeologists dig up 60000 ancient
story: NewsArchaeologists dig up , ancient skeletons buried near Londons Euston Station in -year old cemeterySt James Gardens, the resting place of several historic figures, is being excavated to make way for the new HS high-speed rail link despite campaigns against the plansShareCommentsByHana Carter:,  NOV NewsCaptain Matthew Flinders was buried in the site "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWork to dig up , skeletons near London Euston has begun, despite campaigners battling to leave the bodies in peace. The -year-old burial ground at St James Gardens is being excavated by a team of more than  archaeologists as part of the HS high-speed rail project. Coffins containing the bones of people laid to rest from  to , with some belonging to influential people in history. Captain Matthew Flinders, one of Britains most prolic explorers, known for being responsible for navigating and naming Australia was buried in the graveyard.  Bill Richmond, the first black boxer to reach international recognition, who travelled from America to England in  was laid to rest in the Camden plot. Lord George Gordon, who in  called for the repeal of the Catholic Relief Act and ato the repression of Catholics. So far, archaeologists have uncovered the bones of , people from the former th and th-century burial ground in what has been branded Britains largest archaeological exploration. Similar digs along the -mile HS route have unearthed Victorian time capsules, Neolithic tools and medieval pottery. The route will explore treasure troves full of prehistoric, roman and world war relics.  The dig in Camden will add to our understanding of how this city transformed, HS officials said. Originally the work was furiously rejected by campaigners in Camden who branded the work to expand Euston station as outrageous. Dorothea Hackman, a local churchwarden who helped to organise the private memorial service, said  people are being allowed to gather at the now-closed St James Gardens to pay respect to the people buried there.  Its quite outrageous they are going to dig up our dead, she said. They shouldnt be disturbed by spurious activities like this. Campaigners have also protested that a memorial service should be held to honor the disturbed dead. As well as upset over the exhumation of the bodies, trees will also be removed to make way for the high-speed rail line.  Anne Stevens, the vicar of neighbouring St Pancras Church, chained herself to one of the trees in January. In retaliation, an HS spokesman said: Though the former burial ground at St James Gardens has not been in use for more than  years, we will ensure that we treat the site with dignity, respect and care. Bosses at HS are working with Historic England, the Church of England and the local parish to plan the reburial of the remains. This is not the first time that the dead have been disturbed at St James Gardens. In August  the burial ground was transformed into public gardens. Then in the late th century a quarter of graves were partly or entirely removed for work on Euston station.

story: NewsCampaigners say Brexit is “opportunity of letime” to end cruel and illegal puppy smugglingThe Dogs Trust wants MPs to rewrite pet travel legislation to plug EU loopholes which see hundreds of dogs shipped , miles from Eastern Europe in sickening conditionsShareCommentsByKaren Rockett:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsMP and ex-Coronation Street actress Tracey Brabin backs the campaign"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCampaigners say Brexit will finally give Britain “an opportunity of a letime” to end the cruel and illegal puppy smuggling trade. The Dogs Trust wants MPs to rewrite pet travel legislation to plug EU loopholes which see hundreds of pregnant and underage dogs shipped , miles from Eastern Europe in sickening conditions. The call comes as an investigation by the charity predicts a rise in smuggling in the run-up to Christmas as demand for younger, cuter dogs increases online. The charity’s Veterinary Director Paula Boyden said: “We’re calling on the Government to take urgent action to stop the illegal importation of puppies into the UK as Brexit approaches.  “Our investigations revealed shocking welfare conditions.There is no regard for the lives of these vulnerable puppies, subjected to gruelling journeys of over  hours in hot, cramped, filthy conditions with no toilet breaks and very little water. “Some don’t survive – and those who do may have physical health and behavioural issues due to their poor start in le. “Puppy smugglers are only concerned with making a profit, and the UK is an attractive market.Unsuspecting British shoppers will continue to buy puppies online in the run up to Christmas which may have been brought here illegally – the risk of bringing a puppy from Eastern Europe with diseases and behavioural problems into the home is very real. “With Brexit close, this is an opportunity of a letime to put robust measures in place that protect dogs and the public. “We urge the government to take forward our recommendations.”

story: NewsCouple kept  pets in mini-zoo inside smelly and flea-ridden semi-detached house of horrorsDavid Knight and Natalie Keenan, from Stoke-on-Trent, admitted animal cruelty chargesShareCommentsByKathie McInnes:,  NOV NewsDavid Knight and Natalie Keenan, from Stoke-on-Trent, admitted cruelty charges. "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple who kept  pets in a semi-detached house of horrors have been banned from having animals after the extent of their cruelty came to light. The mini-zoo containing a fox, barn owl and bearded dragon was discovered by chance when meter man executed a warrant for unpaid gas at David Knight and Natalie Keenans Stoke-on-Trent home. He alerted the RSPCA, which sent officers round to investigate a home that stank of neglect, with piles of dog poo in the kitchen, rotting chickens in a snake tank and animals covered in fleas. Sadly, a terrier-typer dog called Lexi was in such a bad state she had to be put down, the Stoke Sentinel reports. North Staffordshire Justice Centre heard that other creatures were being kept in small cages, with barely enough room to move and without ready access to water.  Now -year-old Knight has pleaded guilty to five charges related to animal cruelty, while Keenan has also admitted four offences under the Animal Welfare Act. Hazel Stevens, prosecuting on behalf of the RSPCA, said Lexi was experiencing ‘signicant suffering’. She was virtually blind, emaciated with protruding bones, had little fur and an infected tumour that was hidden underneath a ‘foul-smelling mess’. The dog was found curled up on a pile of dirty nappies and had to be carried out of the house as she couldn’t walk. The couple also had a French bulldog called Mocha and a cat called Gizzy, which both had skin and flea problems. As well as a barn owl and fox caged up in separate rooms, a racoon dog, rat, bearded dragon, African grey parrot, five snakes and eight degus were found at the property. The court was told that the menagerie began building up after -year-old Keenan’s father died and she turned to animals for comfort. Charlie had been her dad’s pet and had even acquired his local accent and habit of swearing.  After a rescue centre allowed her to ‘adopt’ the parrot, she soon found other pets to keep them company. The exotic creatures who arrived at the rented property in Sandon Old Road included species that were ‘prey and predator’ and needed specialist care. But they were simply left indoors. Andrew Bennett, representing Knight, said: “They had gone completely overboard – too many animals, too short of space and owners who were suffering on top of that.” Keenan was experiencing mental health problems and felt ‘swamped’. To add to the chaos, the house was in dire need of repair as the ceiling was collapsing and the fridge had flies in it due to electrical problems. The rooms had an accumulation of grime and ingrained dirt and the beds were flea-ridden. Scott Ashdown, representing Keenan, said: “There were also problems with flooding and damp. They went with temporary fixes.” But the court heard that since the animals were removed from the home in November , the couple have managed to get their lives back in order.  Sentencing the pair, District Judge Timothy Boswell told them: “The most signicant mitigation in this case is the progress you have made. The home today is a vast improvement. But he added: “The sheer number of animals whose welfare was ignored fell far below the standard expected.” He disqualied the defendants from keeping animals for three years. They were each handed a -month community order, with a requirement to complete  days of a rehabilitation activity, and both of them must pay pound to help cover the RSPCA’s boarding costs and an pound surcharge. Speaking after the case, RSPCA inspector Charlotte Melvin recalled feeling physically sick at seeing the state the animals had been living in.  She said: When I arrived at the property the couple wouldn’t let me inside so I waited outside for over two hours until police arrived. “During that time they carried bin bag after bin bag of rubbish out of the house. “When I finally went inside it wasn’t what I was expecting at all. Even though they’d been clearing out for two hours it was still absolutely filthy and the animals were being kept in horrying conditions.  “There was cage after cage and animal after animal. The rooms were strewn with rubbish, all of the animals’ accommodation was filthy and their welfare needs were clearly not being met. “It was disgusting and it was mass-scale neglect.” The French bulldog gained  per cent in body weight within two weeks after being rescued by the RSPCA. Apart from Lexi, all the pets are now in the process of being re-homed.

title: dominos most loyal customer sheds
story: NewsDominos most loyal customer sheds NINE STONE after doctors warned her knees might buckleClaudia Whitman tipped the scales at  stone after gorging on pizza and junk foodShareCommentsByKate Mcmullin:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsClaudia Whitman tipped the scales at  stone because of her unhealthy lestyle "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA student who each day gorged on crisps, cake, chocolate and takeaways has shown off her extraordinary weight loss. Claudia Whittam, , was addicted to Domino’s Two-for-Tuesday pizza deal piled on so much weight her doctors warned her knees could buckle. She was also warned she could be left infertile because of her unhealthy lestyle, the Liverpool Echo reports. After ballooning to a   dress size Claudia was given a rude awakening by doctors. She said she would look forward to Tuesdays so she could order two large  inch pizzas for the price of one - and wolf down both in one sitting.  Health professionals warned hershe continued her unhealthy ways not only could she need knee replacements in later le, but could also be left infertile. And it was at that point that Claudia vowed to change her lestyle and shed the pounds and to date has lost a whopping NINE STONE lbs. Claudia from Formby said: I had always struggled with my weight ever since I was in primary school. “My Mum was the same and was keen for me not to go through the same problems. “She would tell the dinner ladies not to give me second and third helpings at lunch time and tried to make me eat healthily, but I think having watched her with her weight it was inevitable that I would also struggle.”  Throughout her teenage years and in to her twenties Claudia continued to pile on the pounds and said she would “pretty much eat everything she shouldn’t”. She said: “I wouldn’t eat breakfast, I would just snack on chocolates and cakes and lunch was like cheese paninis or cheesy pasta’s- I don’t think I had anything without cheese on. “I was Domino’s most loyal customer and would order every Tuesday because it was buy one get one free. “So I would order two large pizzas, either pepperoni and ham and pineapple or margarita and tuna and sweetcorn.  “I would tell my mum that I would keep one for tomorrow, but would then end up eating both in one night.” Claudia - who works part time at a financial advisory firm - said on her way home from work, she would stock up on junk food and then scoff the fatty treats before her tea. She said: “My mum used to say I was addicted to crisps because I would eat two to three big packets a day. “If we ran out in the house I would have to go and buy some more. “Every night I would call in at Tesco and stock up on crisps, sweets and chocolate and then go home, put my pjs on and eat them all.  “And that was as well as eating my tea which would probably be pizza or something with cheese.” But her bad habits soon began to take their toll on Claudia who, aged , dropped out of university and became almost a recluse. She said: “I was so unhappy in myself. “I wasn’t wanting to go out anywhere because I hated having to get dressed up as I knew nothing was going to fit me. “I basically became a recluse. “I was suffering with really low moods and was just in a really bad place. “I just couldn’t do anything I wanted to do, even going up stairs was a struggle and I wouldn’t be able to walk for long periods of time because my legs would hurt from carrying around my weight.”  But it was when she went to the doctors that she was given the shock she needed to make a change. She said: “I was at my heaviest of  stone and I went to the doctors and they basically said I was at risk of all these health problems. “I was at risk of diabetes and they told me my weight could stop me having kids. “They even said I could need knee replacements in the future because my knees wouldn’t be able to hold my body weight. “It scared me. “Because I wanted to be able to go out with my friends and one day have kids and a family and I wasn’t going to be able to do any of these thingsI didn’t lose weight.” Claudia, said she had previously tried “quick fix diets” and had also joined Slimming World once before with her mum in .  However she said this time she was determined and re-joined her local group at the Dove Centre in Formby which is run by consultant Carol Wylie. And she was amazed when the weight began to drop off her. She said: “It was hard to begin with because I was used to being able to eat whatever I wanted but I soon realised I could still have things I liked, just in moderation. “I lost weight quite quickly and was losing half a stone in two weeks and within a year I had lost the majority of my weight.” Claudia has so far dropped an incredible st lb, and now weighs st lb - with her obese frame a distant memory. Even more amazingly she has managed to drop a staggering seven dress sizes and is now a size  . But the biggest change Claudia has noticed in herself is her confidence and her weight loss has allowed her to do something she has always dreamed of. She said: “I have always been interested in performing arts and have sang since I was a young girl. “So when I started to lose the weight I decided to join a dance class and was shocked when I could actually keep up with the others. “I had always wanted to go to university and I know now that it was my weight that jeopardised my course and made me to drop out the first time. “So I applied for a performing arts degree and had to audition and I got offered a place.” Claudia, who is now studying at Edge Hill University, dances twice a week, is part of a cheerleading team and a strength class - and said she is even nearly able to do the splits. She added: “I just love being active now. “My mum used to be the one telling me to get up and do things and now she is telling me to slow down. “But it’s like I can finally do everything I have wanted to do now. “I am trying to make up for lost time and I just want to give everything a go. “I love going out with my friends, whereas before I would make up excuses and shy away from photos but it’s not a problem now. “I love getting dressed up too. I think the only bad thing about my weight loss is the amount of clothes I have bought.” Claudia added: “My friends and colleagues can just see what a better person I am now and how much I have come out of my shell. “I will have banter in work whereas before I just kept myself to myself. “I think my mum is the most proud of me though as she has always wanted me to do it.” And Claudia has some advice for others trying to lose weight. She said: “Join Slimming World, but do it for yourself. “Quick fixes don’t work. “Slimming World makes you change the way you look and feel about food. “The changes I’ve made were so simple – little things like switching white bread for wholemeal and using low-calorie cooking spray instead of lots of oil. “And now I can live my le to my full potential. “No more hiding.”

The mum-to-be impressed fashion-lovers with her incredible looks - covering everything from comfy casual to red carpet glam from high street names, as well as designer brands. And communication coach Robin Kermode believes the pregnant duchess, , used her strategically picked attire to signal her strongly held beliefs. In total, it is estimated Meghans Down Under tour wardrobe cost pound,. The items of clothing with signicant meanings behind them include her pumps created out of recycled plastic water bottles, and jeans made by female victims of human trafficking and sexual exploitation. With the world of the eyes upon her, some of Meghans outfits have unsurprisingly sold out as fans rush to snap them up. The jeans made by female victims of sexual exploitation  On several occasions during the overseas tour, Meghan opted to wear jeans from Outland - including the Harriet pair, pictured above. The Australian brand was founded by James Bartle after he saw first-hand how human traffickers prey on vulnerable young girls in order to service the sex industry. Determined to making a change, James learnt that once a girl has been rescued and supported through her recovery, a sustainable career path is vital for securing her future. He created the Denim Project, to enable those girls who demonstrated an interest in sewing to put their new skills to use. Outlands team of seamstresses offer positions to those at risk of falling into poverty, and has broadened its mission to set a standard for the treatment and remuneration of young female workers in the garment manufacturing industry. It also sources ethically and environmentally sound raw materials, from organic cotton pocket linings to recycled packaging. After the Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced their engagement, they asked people who wanted to mark the occasion to donate to charities they had picked instead of giving them wedding gts. One of these charities included the Myna Mahila Foundation, which empowers women in Mumbai’s urban slums, by providing them with a trusted network, where they are supported professionally and personally to help them grow as iniduals and businesswomen. Thus Meghans Outland jeans reflect her desire to help vulnerable women which she has spoken so openly about. The vegan leather trainers  Meghan went comfy and casual as she donned white Veja V trainers while on a boat trip in Sydney during the Invictus Games. The trainers got everyone talking as they are environmentally friendly, and made from raw materials sourced from organic farming and ecological agriculture. Some of the shoes also use recycled plastic bottles and many have soles made from wild Amazonian rubber. The French fashion brands founders, Seacutebastien Kopp and Franccedilois-Ghislain Morillion visited clothing and food factories in South America, Asia and Australia while running a nonprofit group — and were appalled by what they saw. So in , they founded Veja in France with the vision of making trainers using the most ecological materials and ethical suppliers they could find. Fashion fans were delighted when they saw Meghan wearing a pair and the duchess is keen on environmental and conservation causes. The recycled plastic bottle pumps  Meghan wore Rothys flats twice on tour, including during a beach clean-up in Melbourne. The pumps are made from recycled plastic water bottles that would otherwise have been destined for landfill - and have been dubbed the most politically correct shoes on the planet by Vogue. The insoles on all of Rothy’s shoes contain recycled foam the rubber soles are made without environmentally stressful black carbon. The yarn comes from plastic and even the packaging’s made from post-consumer recycled materials. Meghan supports charity Surfers Against Sewage, which is a national marine conservation and campaigning charity. It inspires, unites and empowers communities to take action to protect oceans, beaches, waves and wildle. Hugo Tagholm, chief executive of the charity said: Our work as a national marine conservation charity empowers tens of thousands of volunteers annually to protect beaches for everyone. We are currently focused on tackling plastic pollution and this support will help us move towards our vision of Plastic Free Coastlines.” So it is very fitting Meghan wore the pumps during the beach visit - signalling her passion to protecting the sea from plastic. The sustainable brand  The Duchess of Sussex wore a stunning custom-made silk wool cocktail dress in dark navy by Gabriela Hearst at Government House in Wellington. The sustainable luxury brand is based on a less is more approach. Gabriela is a notable feminist designer and political activist. She wanted to create a brand that reflects a slower pace and process: where things are made with care and detail, where tradition is more important than trend, where there is a purpose to every piece, according to her website. She takes into consideration where materials come from and who is making them. Meghan wore the dress to deliver a speech to honor the th anniversary of female suffrage. The empowering dress  Meghan looked sensational when she wore a beautul white Theia dress for dinner with the King and Queen of Tonga. The label is inspired by the Greek Goddess Theia, who had an incredible power to turn everything that she gazed on to light. The Theia dresses are designed to make women feel confident – similar to Meghan’s beliefs. The website explains about their collection: Inspired by the Greek Goddess Theia, this evening wear, bridal and day dress collection was created to bring out every womans inner goddess. One of the original Titans, Theia, who ruled during the Greek Golden Age, possessed the incredible power of light which radiated from her sparkling eyes. All that she gazed upon glittered, becoming luminous and radiant. She imbued gold and silver with their shine. She gave diamonds their fire and rubies and emeralds their sparkle. Her three children Helios the sun, Celene the moon, and Eos the dawn, all continue to bring light in to the world everyday. The woman who wears Theia will be filled with confidence knowing her dress fits wonderfully and looks beautul on her, thus naturally allowing her inner goddess to shine. Ron Easton was found in a gulley on his flat roof at Bigbury-on-Sea in Devon on  October after his neighbour became worried at a build up of milk bottles and newspapers. It is believed that he climbed onto the house extension using a ladder. The pensioner, known locally as Ton-Up Ron after his love of cars, was stuck on his roof for three days before emergency services were alerted. A  call describing the moment he was found on the roof still breathing has also been released.  He was airlted to Derrord Hospital in Plymouth but died on Friday, his family said. Louise Wainwright, editor of newsletter Bigbury News, said the incident had raised questions about community and checking on neighbours. Ron was a very private man... its very sad, she said.  Hazel Osborne, who watched the rescue operation told PlymouthLive : Hes an incredible old boy who still drives his MG sports car. He was a rally driver who once drove in the Dakar rally. It was her friend who raised the alarm, she said: The fire service and ambulance were here. There were paramedics and first responders and then the Devon Air Ambulance arrived and you could see clouds of dust.  A spokesperson for Devon  Somerset Fire Service told PlymouthLive: He appears to have climbed on to his house extension on a ladder. We sent three appliances and an aerial ladder  to the scene. The space to work in was far too narrow for our aerial , so firefighters used a stretcher from ambulance to climb up onto the roof and rescue him. Villagers paid tribute to the pensioner and lowered their flag to half mast as a mark of respect.

story: NewsMum-of-three who paid £, to dating agency which failed to find her boyfriend "no longer has dreams"Tereza Burki, , won a court case earlier this year after she claimed "exclusive" agency Seventy Thirty had misled herShareCommentsByJames BrewsterDave Burke:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video upmarket-dating-agency-seven-thirty-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA orced mum-of-three who paid pound, to an exclusive dating agency which failed to find the man of her dreams says she no longer has dreams. Tereza Burki, , earlier this year won a court case when a judge ruled she had been misled, and was given her money back. But she said the case has given her little satisfaction. She had hoped to find a fulfilling relationship and possibly a fourth child, but Seventy Thirty Ltd failed to deliver. Describing her experience to the Daily Mail , she said: I’m finding it hard right now.  I no longer have dreams. I used to dream of meeting someone, of having a future, when I went to these people. She told the newspaper that material things dont matter so much now, and she fears her child-bearing years are behind her. Ms Burki, a private wealth consultant, said she wanted to believe the Cinderella story when she signed up with the agency. The agency was unable to find her the man of her dreams and possibly the father of her child, she told the High Court. She said the agency assured her it only dealt in creme de la creme matches and could introduce her to bachelors you dream of meeting. When she signed up with the agency in , Ms Burkis requirements for the men she wanted to meet were not modest, Judge Richard Parkes QC said.  She wanted a wealthy man with a lestyle similar or more affluent than her own and, ideally, multiple residences. But the most important factor for Ms Burki, who lives in Cha, where homes sell for millions, was that her soulmate would be prepared to have more children, as she wanted four. But today Mr Parkes ordered the agency to repay her fee, ruling that she had been deceived by Seventy Thirtys then managing director. He told the court: Gertrude Stein quipped that whoever said money cant buy happiness didnt know where to shop. This case is about a woman looking for romantic happiness who says she was tricked into shopping in the wrong place, paying a large sum to a dating which, she says, made promises but failed to produce the goods.  Upholding Ms Burkis claim , he ruled the agencys then managing director, Lemarc Thomas, guilty of deceit in misleading her. Although the agency boasted of more than , members, the truth was that only about  of them were men actively looking for love, he said. And the management consultant would never have paid her money and joined up had Mr Thomas not knowingly given her a wholly  impression. Agency founder, Susie Ambrose, said Seventy Thirty had successfully matched over , lonely hearts and  babies had been born since she set it up in . But the judge said Mr Thomas had told Ms Burki that there were a substantial number of wealthy men on the agencys books, actively looking for matches. She had no means of checking the truth of what he told her, and no reason to doubt it, he added. And she relied on Mr Thomass word before spending a large amount of money on a dating agency in the hope of finding a partner who would give her a fourth child. The Knightsbridge-based agency claimed to have about , active members and that Ms Burki had been sent five potential matches that fit her requirements soon after joining. But the judge said: My conclusion from the evidence is that there are at the very most perhaps  active members of Seventy Thirty, and probably fewer. That points to a maximum of around  active male members. A membership of  active men cannot by any stretch of the imagination be described as a substantial number, he continued. The representations made by Mr Thomas were therefore  and misleading. The judge accepted that the agency did have a sizeable database and was not a fundamentally dishonest or fraudulent operation. He emphasised that he had not found that it was not an effective matchmaking agency or that it did not in the event provide Ms Burki with suitable matches. And, had Mr Thomas told her the truth, Ms Burki would have had little cause for complaint. But he added: What I have found is that Mr Thomas ly represented the size of the active membership of Seventy Thirty to Ms Burki and induced her to pay a substantial fee on the strength of his deceit. Had Ms Burki known what the true size of the active membership was, she would not have joined Seventy Thirty. Worried about running out of time to have another child, she felt very let down and disappointed by the fact that Mr Thomass claims for the service turned out to be untrue. And, as well as giving her her money back, the judge awarded her pound for the disappointment and sadness she suffered. Her total award came to pound,. Against that, Ms Burki was ordered to pay Seventy Thirty pound, in libel damages after writing a damning Google review of the agency, describing it as a scam. Ms Burki has not proved that Seventy Thirty lacked the means or intention to operate an effective match making service, let alone that it was engaged in a fraudulent scheme to extract money from its clients for the benefit of its founder the judge ruled. Giving evidence during the case, Miss Burki told the judge: You shouldnt promise people who are in a fragile state of mind, in their mid-s, the man of their dreams. You are entrusting a service you believe is professional, who will take care of your interests and have your best interests at heart.

story: NewsSchoolboy asylum seeker leaves school after playground rumours he was really  years oldEXCLUSIVE: The pupil is said to have arrived here without paperwork from Germany - telling immigration officials he was ShareByLouie Smith:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsParents are concerned that the teenage asylum seeker may be much older"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA schoolboy claimed his classmate’s full beard sparked rumours he was a grown man – and that led to a Home Office investigation. The year  pupil said of the alleged asylum seeker from Iran: “He looks way older than many of the teachers. It’s like someone’s dad has come into school. “He’s got a big beard, while the other boys I know are struggling to grow little moustaches. He’s very tall, around ft I’d say.” The boy, who does not want to be named, added: “When I heard he was actually  years old I immediately told my mum.” She contacted Stoke High School in Ipswich, Suffolk, to complain. She said: “It’s nothing personal about him whatsoever. I feel this is a massive safeguarding issue.”  The pupil is said to have arrived here without paperwork from Germany, telling immigration officials he was . He started school in September but has not been attending in recent days. One mum defended him and his right to an education saying: “I don’t have an issue with it until I see some real proof other than all the hearsay and rumours.” But on Snapchat, a pupil asked: “How’s there a -year-old man in our maths class ” There have also been playground rumours about a year  pupil the boy spends time with.  Our schoolboy source said: “I have heard rumours that the boy is his son. But I have also seen him point at the younger boy and say, ‘My brother, my brother’.” In a statement, the Ormiston Academies Trust, said: “This is a matter for the Home Office and we have referred it to them. “The student is not attending school at this time. We followed Government and local authority policies and guidance.” A Home Office source said the investigation into the boy’s age was being treated “seriously”.

title: teen yob who pelted vulnerable
story: NewsSnapchat yob who pelted vulnerable woman with flour and eggs says HES now too scared to leave his homeCohan Semple says hes received "death threats from random people" after the sickening attack on mum-of-one Janice Morris in Bury St Edmunds, SuffolkShareByLouis SmithSophie Evans:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsCohan Semple humiliated the vulnerable woman by pelting her with flour and eggs "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenage yob who humiliated a vulnerable woman by pelting her with flour and eggs is now too scared to leave his home, it is reported.Cohan Semple says hes struggling to leave his house amid death threats following the sickening attack on -year-old Janice Morris. The teenager was among five boys who targeted Janice as she sat on a park bench in Suffolk in what a court heard was a despicable attack.An image showing them smiling and pointing at their cowering victim sparked widespread revulsion after being posted on Snapchat and Facebook. Until this week, the boys - all between  and  years old at the time - had had their identities protected because of their age. But Semple turned  last week, meaning he could be unmasked for the first time. Speaking out yesterday, the teenager - who pleaded guilty to threatening behaviour - described how he has received death threats from strangers.He told Sun Online: I’m struggling to leave the house at the moment. Since those pictures have gone on Facebook, I’ve had death threats from random people. Askedhe wanted to apologise for the attack in Bury St Edmunds, he reportedly said he was not ready because of the death threats sent to him online.Semple and his friends faced online abuse and direct threats from people who were sickened by the picture after it was shared online. Yesterday, presiding magistrate Simon Islett told the younger members of the group they could have faced jail termsthey were a few years older. He described the incident as a despicable attack on a vulnerable woman and said it was “terrying” for the mum-of-one.Mr Islett told one boy: “She didn’t know what was going to happen or what the outcome was going to be.  You have got to put yourself in the victim’s place and consider your actions and the effect it might have on them.” Janice was sitting in a park when she was approached by Semple and the group. Ipswich Youth Court heard they began asking questions about drugs before one of the boys spat in her face. Prosecutor Wayne Ablett said: He came from behind the bench and spat at her, with spit landing on her face. She said, What did you do that for  She recalls the boy laughing at her, then spitting at her again. Magistrates heard the group disappeared for around  minutes, then ed with flour bought at a nearby shop. Mr Ablett said: These items were chucked at and thrown at her body, covering her completely in flour. The boys were still laughing. She was spat at again and one of them had taken a photo of her. She heard one of them say, Were filming it.  The boys were arrested after the incriminating photo appeared on Facebook in July this year. Janice suffered no physical injuries but was left severely distressed by her ordeal. Semple, who admitted threatening behaviour, lives in Bury St Edmunds with his mum. The court heard since the incident he had received death threats, and felt remorseful and sorry for what happened. Declan Gallagher, defending Semple, said: He took the photograph and put it on his own Snapchat. One of his circle then took a screenshot of that, then it went onto Facebook, then it went beyond. He was released on bail, to be sentenced at an adult court on December . Four other boys, aged , ,  and , admitted the same offence yesterday and were sentenced to -month referral orders. They were also ordered to pay pound each in compensation to the victim. A sixth defendant, aged , denied using threatening behaviour and will face trial at the youth court on February .

title: text messages sent couple who
story: NewsText messages sent by couple who left baby girl to die in monstrous cage revealedLauren Coyle, , and her boyfriend Reece Hitchcott, , were found guilty of child cruelty at Liverpool Crown CourtShareCommentsByJonathan Humphries:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsEllie-Mays mum Lauren Coyle was cleared of manslaughter "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailText messages sent by a mum and her boyfriend who left a baby girl to die in a monstrous cage have been revealed. Toddler Ellie-May Minshull-Coyle was tied to the mattress of her bed with tight ligatures across her chest and legs and a duvet placed over her, Liverpool Crown Court was told A jury heard how her bedroom had been transformed into a monstrous cage. The window had also been blocked with a mattress and there were no lights. Ellie-Mays mum Lauren Coyle, , and her boyfriend Reece Hitchcott, , were cleared of manslaughter, the Liverpool Echo reported. After almost seven-and-a-half hours of deliberations, the jury found the pair guilty of causing or allowing her death, one count of child cruelty by caging the child in her bed, and another count of child cruelty by restraining her in the bed.  Their lodger, Connor Kirby, , of Liverpool, was found not guilty of all of the charges A post-mortem examination carried out by Dr Alison Armour, a Home Office consultant forensic pathologist, concluded the childs death was caused by forcible restraint by ligatures in a face-down position complicated by hyperthermia. During the trial, prosecutor Christopher Tehrani, QC, read out a series of text messages between Coyle and Hitchcott, which between the couple following Ellie-Mays birth. Hitchcott sent a message which read: I will get it dont worry why the f*** have been like this today i have done f*** all wrong.  Coyle replied: Dont treat me like that bloody let you borrow pound when that could have gone on Ellies trainers. Hitchcott replied: Alright for you to be like that with me wtf Coyle replied: Cant be arsed with it anymore you owe money now pay it. Coyle soon began to complain to her boyfriend that Ellie-May was keeping her awake at night. Her text read: Ellie keeps waking up have to take in living room dont want to go to bed yet. Coyle often messaged her boyfriend while he was at work, the court heard.  On one occasion Hitchcott sent her a message which read: I love you baby this one of the ways it will teach her slowly that she needs to sleep on her own. On February   Coyle posted a message on her Facebook page which read: Finally got my little princess in a routine in her big bed. She is growing up far too fast. Coyle sent a message to Hitchcott which read: Stressed with Ellie. She was biting me so I put her in her room. She is banging her head off the walls. I have smacked her loads too. Hitchcott replied: I will sort her out when I come home. I will put her in her room. Coyle replied: I literally feel like jumping n front of a train. So stressed.  Hitchcott replied: I will sort it out baby. On another occasion Coyle sent a text to her boyfriend which read: There she goes ahead banging her f***ing head again. On March  Coyle sent a message to Hitchcott which read: Ellie playing up again shoved her in her room. Hitchcott replied: She will behave when I am home ha ha. Mr Tehrani also told the court that Ellie-Mays medical condition deteriorated in the months leading up to her death. The toddler suffered from vomiting and diarrhea, and a doctor said that she was suffering from gastroenteritis. The case was adjourned for sentencing at a later date.

title: tiny miniature detached house once
story: NewsTiny miniature detached house once home to eight goes on the market for £,The minuscule one-up, one-down in Stanton Drew, Somerset is on the market for £,ShareCommentsByMirror:,  NOV NewsThe adorable miniature house in Stanton Drew is on the market for £, "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA tiny detached property that once squeezed a family of eight into its rafters is up for sale. The adorable one-up, one-down has a floor plan that reaches the dizzy heights of  square feet. The thatched hexagonal home is a well known landmark in Stanton Drew, a Somerset village about  miles south of Bristol. Originally constructed in , the buildings first le was as a toll house, collecting fees from those heading west towards the coast, The Bristol Post reported.  It is said a money pouch used to hang on a hook over the front door, into which coach drivers would drop their fares as they passed freely along the road. But by , The Round House was already a residential dwelling. Village folk say a family of eight once lived within its small confines, with bunk beds built amid the roof rafters. The exposed beams remain today – but it still takes some imagination to see how eight people once fit. The hexagonal internal accommodation of the Round House includes an open plan kitchen and living area as well a modern shower room on the ground floor.  A narrow twisting staircase leads to a double bedroom which has a vaulted ceiling with exposed beams, and enjoys a lovely countryside aspect. Chapel shaped windows with shutters, an arched entrance door and an out of service post box all add to the charm of the property. While living inside the house may not be for the claustrophobic – step outside and you have all the space you could want. While the actual plot of land is effectively a patch of grass between roads, the unspoilt countryside at the heart of the Chew Valley would be on your doorstep.  The Round House fits well within Stanton Drew, which has a range of listed buildings dating from the th to th centuries as well as a primary school, pub, church and village hall. It is within a comfortable commute of Bristol or Bath, while a school bus runs to the popular Chew Valley Secondary School. The miniature home is on the market for pound,.

title: mum begs people stop kissing
story: NewsMum whose -day-old baby died from cold sore virus begs people: "Stop kissing babies that are not yours"Presley and Elias Trejo, from Texas, issued the heartbreaking warning after their daughter Emerson Faye died after contracting the Herpes Simplex Virus from someone kissing herShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsDevastated parents have issued a severe warning to others after their baby girl died from the cold sore virus at just  days old "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devastated mum has issued a heartbreaking warning asking people to stop kissing babies which arent yours after her daughter died from the cold sore virus at  days old. Presley and Elias Trejo, from Fort Worth, Texas, welcomed baby girl Emerson Faye on July  but she passed away less than two weeks later after contracting the Herpes Simplex Virus after someone gave her a kiss. Mum Presley took to Facebook to warn others about what can happen when people kiss babies that arent their own.The emotional post, which has been shared more than , times, told of how baby Emerson Faye died after receiving the kiss of death as the virus is particularly harmful to babies because of their weak immune system.  She wrote: Emerson ended up passing away from what is called the HSV- virus. It’s the Herpes Simplex Virus most commonly known as the cold sore virus or the kiss of death for infants. For adults it’s not a big deal. But for infants with little to no immune system, it’s fatal. When someone who has the virus in their system and kisses an infant it can spread rapidly. You can have the virus and not even know you have it. You don’t have to have an active cold sore to pass it on. Presley, who is also mum to two boys, went on to describe how the disease slowly attacked her daughters body. She continued: You shed the virus in your saliva and when it gets on the baby it goes through the body so fast. It attacks the brain first.  It shows up as a type of meningitis. It’s fluid based around the vertebrae and goes straight the the brain. It then spreads to all their organs. It happens so fast that you don’t even know the baby is sick. In Emerson’s case, when we arrive to the hospital, her liver was completely gone. Her kidneys were right behind. Everything was failing. She was having multiple seizures until she was brain dead. Her heart stopped beating and the only thing that kept her alive were machines. My daughter, my own flesh and blood who I created out of love, was on le support and I had to be the one to pull the plug on her le. A mother should never ever have to bury their child. The virus took her at just  days old and we watched her die a very slow death. And now I have a letime without her. Presley then delivered a stark warning to others and said she decided to share her story in order to raise awareness. She added: Everyone needs to know about this virus and what it does to children and their families! PEOPLE!!!! STOP KISSING BABIES THAT ARE NOT YOURS!!!!! WAS YOUR HANDS WHEN YOU ARE AROUND NEWBORNS!!!!! I have seen stories about other infants passing from this same virus but you never think it’s going to happen to you. Well this time, it did. My babies don’t have their sister and my husband and I lost our only little girl.  Doctors don’t see this very often. There’s not a lot of cases on this but it’s starting to sp and more. And now it happened right here to us. Our perfectly healthy, happy, BEAUTIFUL angel is no longer here with us because of a terrible virus that people need to be more aware of. People need to know about this sickness. This is a serious and dangerous illness. Do your part, stop kissing babies and start washing your hands. These babies don’t deserve it. Emerson didn’t deserve it. I, as a mother and we, didn’t deserve it. My husband and kids don’t deserve it. And now we will live a whole le time of what ’s. I will never see her go to kindergarten, graduate high school or college, my husband will never walk her down the aisle on her wedding day, I will never see her be a better mother than me. It’s not fair!! We should have never had to go through this. I love you Emerson Faye. I will carry on your name and your love till eternity. I will never forget you. I will never stop loving you. Fly high beautul baby. The Herpes Simplex Virus causes painful blisters on the mouth or genitals, and is a chronic, long-term condition. There are two types of the virus, HSV  and HSV  and both types can causes cold sores on the mouth, genital herpes, and whitlowson the fingers and hands. Neonatal herpes is extremely dangerous for young babies, because their immune systems have not fully developed to fight off the virus. title: vet reveals one simple move
story: NewsVet reveals one simple move to stop a dog attack after baby girl mauled to death in front of mumWARNING: DISTRESSING CONTENT Veterinarian Brett Levitzke has spoken out after one-year-old Triniti Harrell was mauled to death by her familys pet pitbullShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news us-news video how-stop-dog-attacks-revealed-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA vet has revealed one simple move that could stop a dog attack after a one-year-old girl was mauled to death by a pitbull in front of her screaming mum. Little Triniti Harrell was playing with her mother, Miranda Harrell, in their front yard when their pet dog suddenly attacked and began thrashing her around. In a harrowing  call, a distraught Miranda, from North Carolina, US, could be heard telling the operator, He wont stop!, and Help me, shes dying! After being instructed to do so by the operator, she then bravely ran inside her home, grabbed a kne and tried to slit the throat of the six-year-old pitbull. But heartbreakingly, she could be heard crying: This kne is too dull.  Triniti died in hospital days after the attack last week, WRAL reports. And in the aftermath of the tragedy, veterinarian Brett Levitzke has revealed one little-known move that could help people stop dog attacks. If you pick them up by the hind legs theyre off balance, their first reaction may be to let go and then turn around, he told Inside Edition. There is no suggestion this action could have saved Trinitis le. Other experts have previously said punching the dog in the nose and the muzzle, distracting it with an item of clothing or an accessory, or using your entire body weight on the animal to break its bones could help in the event of an attack. The horric incident on October  could only be stopped when the pitbull was shot dead by an Edgecombe County deputy - who had to fire at it twice.  This was despite Miranda and the  operators efforts to save Triniti. In a recording of the emergency call, the operator asks Miranda: Can you get hold of anything - a pot, pan, shovel, anything youve got around your house  He then tells her to whack the dog right in the centre of the top of his head. He adds: If you hit him hard enough, youll knock him out. But devastatingly, Miranda yells back: He wont stop! The operator continues: Find something and hit him with it. The mum responds: Im hitting him as hard as I can. She then screams a long cry of desperation: Help me! In a last-ditch bid to save Triniti, the dispatcher instructs Miranda to dash into her home in Rocky Mount and grab a weapon like a steak kne.  After the mother replies that she cant leave her daughter alone, he says: It will take you  seconds to run in the house and grab it. He then adds: I need you to go find a kne immediately. The mother replies: OK. After grabbing a kne, she is then told to slit the bottom of her pets neck. The dispatcher says: Grab him by one ear and cut along the bottom of his neck. Hes going to let go. Its going to release his jaw muscles. He tells Miranda the animal wont have a choice but to let go. However, despite her efforts to cut her dog, the mum finds the blade too dull. As she pleads again for help, the operator tells her he needs her to do anything she can do with the weapon to make the pet let go. The dogs le is not a concern to me at this point, he says.  The recording then comes to an end. Triniti was rushed to hospital after the terrying attack. But despite the efforts of medics at UNC Childrens Hospital in Chapel Hill - and other hospitals - to save her le, she passed away just days later. Edgecombe County Sherf Clee Atkinson confirmed her mother had tried to stab the pitbull before a deputy shot it dead at the scene. Speaking to WRAL News after the tragedy, Miranda said: I did all I could. Sherf Atkinson said: Its just one of those incidents. They were playing, having a good time, and the dog reacted at some point. Triniti - who was laid to rest by her loved ones earlier this week - is not the only person to have fallen victim to a dog attack in recent weeks.  In the West Midlands, a teenage girl was reportedly left with her lip hanging off after being savaged by a dog as she walked home from school. Chloe Lloyd, , is said to have suffered le-changing injuries after she was attacked by the animal on Ellerton Walk, Wolverhampton, last month. Her mother Claire Forrester said there was blood everywhere. The same month, a -year-old man was left in a coma after his genitals were ripped off and eaten by a bulldog named Biggie Smalls. The man, who has not been named, was found lying unconscious inside a flat by emergency crews in Haddington, East Lothian, Scotland. It was later reported he had apparently smeared his crotch in peanut butter. And yesterday, footage emerged showing a pitbull launching an attack on a Siberian husky at a dog show in Chiang Mai, Thailand, leaving it bloodied.

title: mcdonalds launches delicious new christmas
story: NewsMcDonalds launches delicious new Christmas drink - and reveals this years festive cupsMcDonalds is the latest food outlet to reveal its Christmas cups - and theyre sure to be a big hit with fansShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe cups are really cute "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMcDonalds has delighted festive fans up and down the country by introducing a brand new Christmas drink. The fast food giant has revealed its new addition - the Millionaire’s Latte - will go on sale next week. The tasty new drink contains a large shot of espresso blended with steamed milk and a caramel biscuit flavour syrup. Its then topped with a swirl of chocolate cream and a caramel drizzle. Yummy! McDonalds has also revealed its new Christmas cups - and theyre definitely Instagram-friendly. title: oumuamua mysterious interstellar asteroid could
story: NewsOumuamua: Mysterious interstellar asteroid could be giant articial solar sail sent by aliens looking for leScientists at the Hard Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics believe Oumuamua - the first ever interstellar object spotted in our solar system - could be a giant light sailShareCommentsByMilo Boyd:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsAn artists impression of Oumuamua, the first observed interstellar object "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe first ever interstellar object in the solar system might be an articial light sail sent to look for signs of le, its claimed. In a study released on Thursday, astronomers at the Hard Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics published their observations of an interstellar object known as Oumuamua. According to the scientists, the rock - which is the first observed to enter our star system from another - received an unexpected boost in speed as it passed through the inner solar system last year. Because the object seems to exhibit qualities associated with both asteroids and comets, the astronomers have speculated its unusual acceleration might be as a result of a light sail of articial origin being pushed by solar radiation. The study Could Solar Radiation Pressure Explain Oumuamuas Peculiar Acceleration  was conducted by Shmuel Bialy, a postdoctoral researcher at the CfAs Institute for Theory and Computationand Professor Abraham Loeb, the director of the ITC, the Frank B. Baird Jr. Professor of Science at Hard University. In the report the astronomers wrote: Considering an articial origin, one possibility is that ‘Oumuamua is a light sail, floating in interstellar space as a debris from an advanced technological equipment.  The asteroid was first spotted by the Haleakala observatory in Hawaii on October  last year. The strange cigar-shape of the object and its unusual behaviour led many to speculate that it might be an alien artefact. In the year since debate has raged in the scientic community as to whether ‘Oumuamua is a comet or an asteroid. The object appeared to speed up as it left the solar system - suggesting it had omitted materials from its surface after being heated by the Sun in a way consistent with a comet.  However, because it did not go through a similar process when it was closest to the Sun, Bialy and Loeb have argued it is in fact a light sail - a form of spacecraft that relies on radiation pressure to generate propulsion Loeb told Universe Today: Oumuamua could be an active piece of alien technology that came to explore our Solar System, the same way we hope to explore Alpha Centauri using Starshot and similar technologies. The alternative is to imagine that `Oumuamua was on a reconnaissance mission. The reason I contemplate the reconnaissance possibility is that the assumption that `Oumumua followed a random orbit requires the production of ~^ such objects per star in our galaxy.  Karen Meech, an astronomer at the University of Hawaiis Institute of Astronomy and co-author of the study, suggested that dust grains on the surface of most comets had eroded away during ′Oumuamuas journey through interstellar space. She said: The more we study ′Oumuamua, the more exciting it gets. Im amazed at how much we have learned from a short, intense observing campaign. I can hardly wait for the next interstellar object! Oumuamua is less than half a mile inand is currently traveling away from the Sun at about , mph as it heads toward the outskirts of the solar system. In another four years, it will pass Neptunes orbit on its way back into interstellar space.
